case_data.name: Lee v. Hertz Corporation
case_data.plaintiff_description: Plaintiff is an African American man offered employment by Hertz.  The offer was revoked after a credit history check which revealed a criminal charge against the plaintiff.  The plaintiff alleges that the defendant violated the FCRA by failing to ask for permission to do the background check and by failing to give him notice and opportunity to correct any errors in the credit report.
case_data.summary:
On June 9, 2015, the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights of the San Francisco Bay Area filed this nationwide class action against the Hertz Corporation and Sterling Infosystems, Inc., on behalf of the plaintiff and all similarly situated applicants. The plaintiffs alleged that Hertz and Sterling systematically violated federal law based on the way they conducted criminal background checks of Hertz job applicants.

Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), employers must provide job applicants with a clear written disclosure in a standalone form and get job applicants' express written consent before conducting a background check. The FCRA also requires that, before denying or revoking a job offer based on background check results, employers must provide the applicant with a copy of the background check and a statement of rights under the FCRA, and give the applicant a reasonable amount of time to respond to the accuracy of the report. Hertz never provided the plaintiffs with a disclosure that it may obtain consumer reports and did not receive the plaintiffs' authorization for such reports.

The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, damages, and attorneys' fees on behalf of himself and others similarly situated. The parties apparently participated in a settlement discussion in June 2015, but we have no record of whether they reached a settlement. The case was voluntarily dismissed by the plaintiff on August 24, 2015.
case_data.summary_short: Plaintiffs alleged violations of the Fair Credit Report Act by Hertz, for failing to get written consent for a background check, failure to provide prospective employees a copy of any background check conducted, and failure to give job applicants a reasonable amount of time to respond to any negative information in the background check.  They filed a putative class action in the Eastern District of California in June 2015. The case was voluntarily dismissed by the plaintiff on August 24, 2015.

1  Plaintiff Peter Lee, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated, alleges, 
2  upon personal knowledge as to himself and upon information and belief as to other matters, as 
3  follows: 
4   INTRODUCTION 
5  1.  Plaintiff Peter Lee (“Plaintiff” or “Mr. Lee”) brings this case as a class action 
6  pursuant to the federal Fair Credit Reporting Act (“FCRA”), 15 U.S.C. § 1681 et seq. against the 
7  Hertz Corporation and its subsidiary, Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, Inc. (“Hertz”), and 
8  Sterling Infosystems, Inc., d/b/a SterlingBackcheck (“Sterling”) (collectively, “Defendants”). 
9  2.  Hertz routinely rejects job applicants, including Mr. Lee, based on information 
10  contained in background check reports (“consumer reports”) that it obtains from background 
11  check companies called “consumer reporting agencies” or “CRAs,” such as Sterling.    
12  3.  In doing so, Hertz fails to strictly comply with federal law governing the 
13  procurement and use of consumer reports for employment purposes. 
14  4.  Sterling, one of the largest consumer reporting agencies in the United States, 
15  provides consumer reports to companies, including Hertz, to be used for employment purposes, 
16  such as making hiring decisions. 
17  5.  In doing so, Sterling fails to strictly comply with federal law governing the 
18  procurement and use of consumer reports for employment purposes. 
19  6.  Specifically, Hertz systematically violates section 1681b(b)(3)(A) of the FCRA 
20  by using consumer reports to make adverse employment decisions without first providing the 
21  applicant who is the subject of the report with sufficient and timely notification of its intent to 
22  take an adverse action, a copy of the report, and a summary of the applicants’ rights under the 
23  FCRA.  15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3)(A)(i) and (ii). 
24  7.  Sterling also violates section 1681b(b)(3)(A) of the FCRA by failing to timely 
25  provide applicants with appropriate pre-adverse action disclosures, including a copy of the 
26  relevant consumer report and a written description of the applicant’s rights under the FCRA, in 
27  violation of FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3)(A)(i) and (ii). 
28 
- 2 -  
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA      
 
 
 

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page3 of 23
 
1  8.  Before procuring consumer reports from Sterling and/or other CRAs, Hertz also 
2  fails to inform job applicants in a clear and conspicuous disclosure in writing, in a document that 
3  consists solely of the disclosure, that it may procure a consumer report for employment purposes, 
4  in violation of U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(2)(A)(i).  
5  9.  Hertz similarly fails to obtain authorization of job applicants in writing to procure 
6  such consumer reports, in violation of U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(2(A)(ii). 
7  10.  Sterling has further violated the FCRA by failing to notify job applicants when it 
8  furnishes consumer reports that are likely to adversely affect the applicants’ ability to obtain 
9  employment and failing to follow strict procedures to ensure the timely and complete nature of 
10  those reports, in violation of U.S.C. § 1681k(a).  
11  11.  Defendants have violated the above-mentioned provisions of the FCRA willfully 
12  and pursuant to their respective companywide policies and procedures.   
13  12.  On behalf of himself and others similarly situated, Plaintiff seeks injunctive and 
14  declaratory relief; statutory and/or actual damages; punitive damages; pre-judgment and post-
15  judgment interest; and reasonable attorneys’ fees, costs, and expenses associated with this action. 
16  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
17  13.  This Court has original subject matter jurisdiction over Plaintiff’s FCRA claims 
18  pursuant to 15 U.S.C. § 1681p and 28 U.S.C. § 1331.  
19  14.  Venue is proper in this District under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(b)(2) because a 
20  substantial part of the events and omissions giving rise to the claims alleged herein occurred in 
21  this District.  
22  15.  This Court has personal jurisdiction over this matter because Defendants conduct 
23  substantial business activity in this District, and because many of the unlawful acts described 
24  herein occurred in this District and gave rise to the claims alleged. 
25  INTRADISTRICT ASSIGNMENT 
26  16.  A substantial part of the events or omissions which give rise to the claims 
27  occurred in San Francisco County and/or adjacent counties in the San Francisco Division, and 
28 
- 3 -  
 
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA 
  

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page4 of 23
 
1  therefore this action is properly assigned to the San Francisco Division pursuant to Local Rule 3-
2  2(c),(d). 
3  PARTIES 
4  Plaintiff 
5    Peter Lee 
6  17.  Plaintiff Peter Lee is an African-American man who lives in Richmond, 
7  California.   
8  18.  In May 2014, while employed in a similar position with a competing company, 
9  Mr. Lee applied and interviewed for the position of counter sales representative with Hertz’s 
10  Dollar/Thrifty-branched rental car location at the San Francisco International Airport.   
11  19.  Mr. Lee and other Hertz job applicants are “consumers” as defined by the FCRA, 
12  15 U.S.C. § 1681a(c). 
13  Defendants 
14    Hertz Corporation 
15  20.  Hertz Corporation operates the Hertz, Dollar, Thrifty and Firefly car rental brands 
16  in more than 11,000 corporate and licensee locations in approximately 140 countries.  
17  21.  Hertz Corporation is the largest worldwide airport general use car rental company 
18  with more than 1,700 airport locations in the U.S. 
19  22.  Hertz Corporation is registered as a Delaware corporation and maintains its 
20  headquarters at 999 Vanderbilt Beach Road in Naples, Florida.   
21  23.  Hertz Corporation owns and operates the relevant Dollar/Thrifty-branded car 
22  rental office located at the San Francisco International Airport at 780 McDonnell Road, San 
23  Francisco, California, through its wholly-owned subsidiary, Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, 
24  Inc. 
25  24.  At all relevant times, Hertz  Corporation has been a “person” using “consumer 
26  reports” of Mr. Lee and similarly situated applicants for “employment purposes,” and has taken 
27  “adverse action” against Plaintiff and similarly situated applicants, as defined under 15 U.S.C. § 
28 
- 4 -  
 
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA 
  

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page5 of 23
 
1  1681a.  These adverse actions have been based wholly or in part on those consumer reports.  
2  Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group  
3  25.  Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, Inc. is wholly owned and operated by the Hertz 
4  Corporation. 
5  26.  There are approximately 340 Dollar and Thrifty corporate locations in the United 
6  States and Canada. 
7  27.  Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, Inc. is a Delaware Corporation and maintains it 
8  headquarters at 5330 E. 31st Street, Tulsa, Oklahoma. 
9  28.  At all relevant times, Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, Inc. has been a “person” 
10  using “consumer reports” of Mr. Lee and similarly situated applicants for “employment 
11  purposes,” and has taken “adverse action” against Plaintiff and similarly situated applicants, as 
12  defined under 15 U.S.C. § 1681a.  These adverse actions have been based wholly or in part on 
13  those consumer reports.  
14  Sterling 
15  29.  Sterling is a private New York-based corporation self-described as “the world’s 
16  largest company focused entirely on background checks,” with some 20,000 customers and 
17  2,700 employees spread among offices in the United States, Canada, the U.K., India, and the 
18  Philippines. 
19  30.  Sterling has enjoyed exponential growth over the past 15 years, with annual 
20  revenue increasing from approximately $7.5 million in 2001 to $250 million in 2013, as 
21  employers increasingly conduct background checks on prospective and current employees. 
22  Sterling’s founder and chief executive officer stated in 2013 that he expected the company to 
23  surpass $1 billion in annual revenue by 2018. 
24  31.  Through a combination of organic growth, an influx in investment capital, and 
25  aggressive pursuit of competitor agencies and complementary firms, Sterling has greatly 
26  expanded its geographic reach, consumer report volume, and annual revenue over the past 15 
27  years. 
28 
- 5 -  
 
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA 
  

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page6 of 23
 
1  32.  As of 2013, Sterling conducted a reported 16 million background searches every 
2  year for employers.    
3  33.  Sterling has maintained an operational center in Mumbai, India since at least 
4  2006.  In November 2013, Sterling reportedly consolidated its global operations there, and 
5  entrusted an executive in the Mumbai office with oversight over global quality assurance in 
6  consumer reports (including the duty to ensure reports’ accuracy and timeliness). 
7  34.  Sterling is a “consumer reporting agency” for purposes of FCRA compliance 
8  pursuant to 15 U.S.C. § 1681a(f), and a “person” as described in 15 U.S.C. § 1681a(a).   
9  STATEMENT OF FACTS 
10  Background Information  
11  35.  Sterling is among the largest of the nation’s employment background screening 
12  companies, i.e., those that provide “consumer reports,” as defined by 15 U.S.C. § 
13  1681a(d)(1)(B), to employers. 
14  36.  In order to provide these consumer reports, Sterling investigates and reviews 
15  public record databases and assembles and/or maintains consumer files which contain public 
16  record information concerning, among other things, the alleged criminal record history of 
17  individuals.  Sterling then sells this information to employers, including Hertz. 
18  37.  Upon information and belief, as part of the services Sterling offers to its employer 
19  customers, Sterling agrees to send FCRA- required “pre-adverse action” notices to consumers on 
20  behalf of its employer-customers.  Upon information and belief, Hertz has contracted with 
21  Sterling to provide this service. 
22  Plaintiff Lee’s Experience 
23  38.  In June 2012, while in Richmond, California, visiting relatives, Mr. Lee was 
24  arrested.  
25  39.  Mr. Lee was subsequently charged with felony possession of a controlled 
26  substance for sale with a gang enhancement (the “June 2012 charges”). 
27  40.  While the June 2012 charges were pending, in May 2014, Hertz personnel 
28 
- 6 -  
 
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA 
  

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page7 of 23
 
1  recruited Mr. Lee to interview for a counter sales representative position with Hertz at its Dollar/ 
2  Thrifty-branded car rental location at San Francisco International Airport. 
3  41.  At the time Hertz recruited him for a position with the company, Mr. Lee worked 
4  for a competitor car rental company in a similar position. 
5  42.  Mr. Lee interviewed for the position with Hertz sometime in the first half of May 
6  2014.  At the close of the interview, Mr. Lee was given an offer of employment, pending the 
7  processing of his application materials. 
8  43.  To begin this process, a Hertz representative instructed Mr. Lee to complete an 
9  online application by following a link sent to him via email.   
10  44.  Mr. Lee completed the online application as instructed. 
11  45.  On May 15, 2014, Mr. Lee received an email from Kimberly Kowallis (“Ms. 
12  Kowallis”), a field recruiter for Hertz, confirming his conditional offer of employment. 
13  46.  On May 27, 2014, after Mr. Lee had passed Hertz’s mandatory drug screening, he 
14  received an email from Ms. Kowallis with a link to an addendum to the Hertz application 
15  specific to California and Hawaii.  The email requested that Mr. Lee complete the online 
16  application addendum.   
17  47.  Mr. Lee completed the online application addendum as instructed.   
18  48.  Also on May 27, 2014, Mr. Lee received an email from Ms. Kowallis with the 
19  subject line “Hertz Orientation Package.”  This email provided information about Mr. Lee’s 
20  onboarding with Hertz. 
21  49.  Ms. Kowallis subsequently scheduled Mr. Lee to begin working for Hertz on June 
22  9, 2014.  After receiving confirmation of his start date with Hertz, Mr. Lee provided a notice of 
23  resignation, effective June 9, 2014, to his then-current employer.  
24  50.  At some point during the processing of Mr. Lee’s application, Hertz obtained one 
25  or more consumer reports from Sterling containing information about Mr. Lee’s background, one 
26  or more of which included information regarding the June 2012 criminal charges pending against 
27  Mr. Lee. 
28 
- 7 -  
 
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA 
  

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page8 of 23
 
1  51.  At no point during the processing of his employment application did Hertz 
2  provide Mr. Lee with a clear and conspicuous disclosure in the form of a written document that 
3  consisted solely of the disclosure, that it may obtain a consumer report for employment purposes, 
4  as required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(2)(A)(i). 
5  52.  Likewise, at no point during the processing of Mr. Lee’s employment application 
6  did Hertz obtain Mr. Lee’s authorization in the form of a written document for the procurement 
7  of a consumer report, as required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(2)(A)(ii). 
8  53.  On June 3, 2014, Mr. Lee received a call from Ms. Kowallis informing him that 
9  Hertz would not hire him because of the criminal history information contained in his 
10  background check.  Ms. Kowallis told Mr. Lee that she could not do anything about his rejection 
11  because the decision was based on “Hertz policy.”   
12  54.  Mr. Lee asked Ms. Kowallis for a copy of the background check information that 
13  Hertz had obtained and was instructed to contact Sterling. 
14  55.  Later that same day, Mr. Lee received an email from Ms. Kowallis confirming 
15  that Hertz had, indeed, rescinded his job offer because he did not meet the company’s 
16  “background qualifications.”  
17  56.  As a result of the criminal history information contained in the consumer report it 
18  procured from Sterling, Hertz stopped the onboarding process, and did not move forward with 
19  the job that it had offered Mr. Lee. 
20  57.  After Ms. Kowallis informed Mr. Lee that he would not be hired because of 
21  criminal history information contained in his background check on June 3, 2014, Mr. Lee 
22  contacted Sterling by phone and requested a copy of the consumer report that Sterling provided 
23  to Hertz in connection with Mr. Lee’s application for employment. 
24  58.  In response to Mr. Lee’s request, sometime on or after June 3, 2014, Sterling sent 
25  Mr. Lee by regular mail a copy of a consumer report prepared by Sterling, which included 
26  information about the June 2012 charges (the “June 3rd package”).  Mr. Lee did not receive a 
27  copy the June 3rd package until sometime after June 3, 2014. 
28 
- 8 -  
 
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA 
  

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page9 of 23
 
1  59.  Sometime on or after June 4, 2014, Sterling sent to Mr. Lee by regular mail an 
2  undated letter that was inaccurately entitled “Pre-Adverse Action Notice,” and which bore Hertz 
3  corporate logo (the “June 4th Letter'”).  Enclosed with the June 4th letter was a copy of a 
4  consumer report prepared by Sterling dated June 4, 2014, which contained information about the 
5  June 2012 charges. 
6  60.  Mr. Lee did not receive the June 4th Letter, which upon information and belief, 
7  was sent by Sterling pursuant to its contract with Hertz, until sometime after June 4, 2014. 
8  61.  The June 4th Letter informed Mr. Lee that, based on a “Criminal Report” 
9  provided by Sterling, Hertz was considering revoking Mr. Lee’s conditional offer of 
10  employment, subject to Mr. Lee successfully challenging the accuracy of the criminal report 
11  information. 
12  62.  At the time that Sterling mailed Mr. Lee the June 3rd package and the June 4th 
13  letter (as well as at the time Mr. Lee received them), however, Sterling had already provided 
14  Hertz with a copy of Mr. Lee’s consumer report containing information about the June 2012 
15  criminal charges, and Hertz had already revoked Mr. Lee’s conditional offer of employment 
16  based upon information contained in that consumer report. 
17  Factual Allegations Common to All Class Members 
18  63.  Employers commonly use criminal background screening reports to determine 
19  employment eligibility.  A significant percentage of these reports, however, contain incomplete, 
20  inaccurate, misleading, or improper records that can erroneously disqualify a job applicant or 
21  employee.  Recognizing this danger, Congress provided strict reporting and disclosure 
22  requirements in the FCRA to ensure that prospective employees have the opportunity to review 
23  reports summarizing their background information and to contest any inaccuracies and illegal 
24  disclosures and/or provide additional information before these reports influence employment 
25  decisions.   
26  64.  The FCRA requires that “before taking any adverse action based in whole or in 
27  part on [a consumer report],” the employer taking the adverse action must provide “the consumer 
28 
- 9 -  
 
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA 
  

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page10 of 23
 
1  to whom the report relates” with: 
2   
(i)  a copy of the report; and 
3 
(ii) a description in writing of the rights of the consumer under this subchapter, as 
prescribed by the [Consumer Financial Protection] Bureau under section 
4 
1681g(c)(3). 
5 
15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3)(A)(i) and (ii).  
6 
65.  The FCRA defines adverse action as either “a denial of employment or any other 
7 
decision for employment purposes that adversely affects any current or prospective employee,” 
8 
or “any action taken or determination that is . . . adverse to the interests of the consumer.”  15 
9 
U.S.C. §§ 1681a(k)(l)(B).   
10 
66.  A consumer reporting agency’s delivery of a consumer report containing 
11 
information likely to prove detrimental to the consumer’s ability to secure employment is an 
12 
“adverse action” in itself under this section.  See Mattiaccio v. DHA Grp., Inc., No. 12 Civ. 1249, 
13 
2014 WL 717780, at *6 (D.D.C. Feb. 26, 2014) (citing Adams v. Nat’l Eng’g Serv. Corp., 620 F. 
14 
Supp. 2d 319, 332 (D. Conn. 2009) (summary judgment denied on grounds that a reasonable jury 
15 
could deem CRA’s delivery of negative consumer report a FCRA “adverse action”)).  
16 
67.  Hertz and Sterling have routinely and systematically failed to provide Plaintiff 
17 
and other job applicants with a copy of their consumer reports prior to taking adverse actions 
18 
against them. 
19 
68.  Hertz and Sterling further have routinely and systematically failed to provide 
20 
Plaintiff and other job applicants with a summary of their rights under the FCRA prior to taking 
21 
adverse actions against them. 
22 
69.  The FCRA also requires that employers “may not procure a consumer report or 
23 
cause a consumer report to be procured, for employment purposes with respect to any 
24 
consumer,” unless: 
25 
 
26  (i)  a clear and conspicuous disclosure has been made in writing to the consumer at 
any time before the report is procured or caused to be procured, in a document 
27 
28 
- 10 -  
 
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA 
  

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page11 of 23
 
that consists solely of the disclosure, that a consumer report may be obtained for 
1 
employment purposes; and  
 
2 
(ii)  the consumer has authorized in writing (which authorization may be made on the 
3  document referred to in clause (i)) the procurement of the report by that person. 
4  15 U.S.C. § 1681b(B)(2)(A)(i) and (ii).   
5  70.  Hertz routinely and systematically violates these provisions by failing to (1) 
6  provide “clear and conspicuous” disclosures in writing, in a document that consists solely of the 
7  disclosures, that a consumer report may be obtained and (2) obtain applicants’ authorization in 
8  writing to procure a consumer reports for employment purposes.   
9  71.  Finally, the FCRA mandates that any consumer reporting agency that “furnishes a 
10  consumer report for employment purposes” and, in so doing, “compiles and reports items of 
11  information on consumers which are matters of public record and are likely to have an adverse 
12  effect upon the consumer’s ability to obtain employment” shall: 
13   
1)  at the time such public record information is reported to the user of such 
14 
consumer report, notify the consumer of the fact that public record 
information is being reported by the consumer reporting agency, together with 
15 
the name and address of the person to whom such information is being 
reported; or 
16 
 
17  2)  maintain strict procedures designed to [ensure] that whenever public record 
information which is likely to have an adverse effect on a consumer’s ability 
18 
to obtain employment is reported it is complete and up to date. 
19  15 U.S.C. § 1681k(a)(1) and (2).  
20  72.  Sterling routinely and systematically fails to provide consumers with timely 
21  notice of its reporting of public-record information likely to have an adverse effect on the 
22  consumer’s ability to obtain employment.  Sterling also routinely and systematically fails to 
23  maintain strict procedures to ensure that the public record information that it reports is complete 
24  and current.  See Poore v. Sterling Testing Sys., 410 F. Supp. 2d 557, 572 (E.D. Ky. 2006) 
25  (expressing concern over the absence of “any information regarding any procedures that Sterling 
26  may employ to ensure” the accuracy of information received from various subsidiaries and 
27 
28 
- 11 -  
 
    Complaint for Violations of FCRA 
  

Case4:15-cv-02545-JSW   Document1   Filed06/09/15   Page12 of 23
 
1  affiliates); Jones v. Sterling Infosystems, Inc., No. 14-cv-3076 (S.D.N.Y.). 
2  73.   In failing to fulfill either of these obligations, Sterling systematically violates 15 
3  U.S.C. § 1681k(a).  
4  74.  Defendants have acted willfully in violating the requirements of the FCRA. 
5  Defendants knew or should have known about their obligations under the FCRA.  These 
6  obligations are well-established by the plain language of the FCRA and in the promulgations and 
7  opinion letters of the Federal Trade Commission. 
8  75.   Despite Defendants’ awareness of their legal obligations, Defendants have acted 
9  consciously in breaching their known duties and depriving Plaintiff and other job applicants of 
10  their rights under the FCRA.  
11  76.  At a minimum, Defendants’ conduct has been reckless in failing to make an 
12  appropriate inquiry to ascertain its obligations under the FCRA. 
13  CLASS ACTION ALLEGATIONS 
14 
77.  Mr. Lee brings this Class Action pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
15 
23 on behalf of himself and five classes of persons. 
16 
78.  Plaintiff asserts the First, Second, Third, and Fourth Causes of Action against 
17 
Hertz and Sterling on behalf of the “FCRA Consumer Report Copy Class” and “FCRA Summary 
18 
of Rights Class” defined as follows: 
19 
 
20 
FCRA Consumer Report Copy Class: All applicants for employment with 
Hertz in the United States within five years of the filing of this complaint through 
21 
the date of final judgment who were subject to an adverse action based in whole 
22  or in part on information contained in a consumer report without receiving a copy 
of the consumer report at least five business days prior to the adverse action, as 
23  required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3)(A)(i). 
 
24 
FCRA Summary of Rights Class: All applicants for employment with Hertz in 
the United States within five years of the filing of this complaint through the date 
25 
of final judgment who were subject to an adverse action based in whole or in part 
26  on information contained in a consumer report without receiving a written 
description of their rights under the FCRA at least five business days prior to the 
27  adverse action, as required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3)(A)(ii). 
28

1 
79.  Plaintiff asserts the Fifth and Sixth Causes of Action against Hertz on behalf of 
2 
the “FCRA Disclosure Class” and the “FCRA Authorization Class” defined as follows: 
3 
 
4 
FCRA Disclosure Class: All applicants for employment with Hertz in the United 
States within five years of the filing of this complaint through the date of final 
5 
judgment about whom Hertz procured a consumer report without providing a 
6  clear and conspicuous disclosure in writing, in a document that consisted solely of 
the disclosure, prior to procuring the consumer report, as required by 15 U.S.C. § 
7 
1681b(b)(2)(A)(i). 
 
8 
FCRA Authorization Class: All applicants for employment with Hertz in the 
United States within five years of the filing of this complaint through the date of 
9 
final judgment about whom Hertz procured a consumer report without obtaining 
10  the applicants’ authorization in writing prior to procuring the consumer report, as 
required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(2)(A)(ii). 
11

12 
“Adverse Public-Record Information Class” defined as follows: 
13 
 
14

Hertz in the United States, except for in New York State, within five years of the 
15 
filing of this complaint through the date of final judgment about whom Sterling 
16  delivered a consumer report to Hertz containing public-record information likely 
to adversely affect the applicant’s ability to obtain employment without either 
17  providing advance notice to the affected applicant or maintaining strict procedures 
to ensure the information reported was complete and up to date, as required by 15 
18 
U.S.C. § 1681k(a).  
 
19 
81.  The members of the FCRA Consumer Report Copy Class, FCRA Summary of 
20 
Rights Class, the FCRA Disclosure Class, the FCA Authorization Class, and the Adverse Public-
21 
Record Information Class are collectively referred to as “Class Members.” 
22

23 
on discovery or legal developments. 
24 
83.  The Class Members identified herein are so numerous that joinder of all members 
25 
is impracticable.  Hertz employs over 30,000 workers worldwide, with the vast majority located 
26 
within the United States.  Although Plaintiff does not know the precise number of job applicants

1  harmed by Defendants’ violations of FCRA, the number is far greater than feasibly could be 
2  addressed through joinder.  The precise number is also uniquely within Defendants’ possession. 
3  84.  There are questions of law and fact common to Class Members, and these 
4  questions predominate over any questions affecting only individual members.  Common 
5  questions include, among others:   
6   
a.  whether Defendants violated FCRA by taking adverse action, based 
7 
wholly or in part on information contained a consumer report, against 
Plaintiff and other members of the FCRA Consumer Report Copy 
8 
Class without first providing them with a copy of the consumer report 
9  and at least five business days to respond, as required by 15 U.S.C. § 
1681b(b)(3)(A)(i); 
10 
 
b.  whether Defendants violated FCRA by taking adverse action, based 
11 
wholly or in part on information contained in a consumer report, 
against Plaintiff and other members of the FCRA Summary of Rights 
12 
Class without first providing them with a written summary of their 
13  rights under FCRA and at least five business days to respond, as 
required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3)(A)(ii); 
14 
 
c.  whether Hertz violated FCRA by failing to provide Plaintiff and the 
15 
FCRA Disclosure Class with a clear and conspicuous disclosure in 
16  writing, in a document that consisted solely of the disclosure, prior to 
procuring their consumer reports for employment purposes, as 
17  required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(2)(A)(i); 
 
18 
d.  whether Hertz violated FCRA by failing to obtain from Plaintiff and 
the FCRA Authorization Class authorization in writing prior to 
19 
procuring their consumer reports for employment purposes, as 
20  required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(2)(A)(ii); 
 
21  e.  whether Sterling violated FCRA by failing either to inform Plaintiff of 
the Adverse Public-Record Information Class of its intent to deliver 
22 
public-record information likely to adversely affect their ability to 
obtain employment or to maintain strict procedures sufficient to ensure 
23 
that the adverse public-record information was complete and up to 
24  date; 
 
25  f.  whether Defendants were willful in their noncompliance with the 
requirements of FCRA;

g.  whether Defendants were negligent in their noncompliance with the 
1 
requirements of FCRA; and 
 
2 
h.  whether equitable remedies, injunctive relief, statutory damages, 
3  compensatory damages, and punitive damages for Class Members are 
warranted.  
4 
 
5  85.  Mr. Lee is a member of the classes he seeks to represent.  Defendants failed to 
6  provide Mr. Lee with a copy of the consumer report or a notice of his rights under FCRA prior to 
7  taking adverse action against him, as required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3)(A) (i) and (ii). 
8  Additionally, Hertz failed to provide Mr. Lee with a clear and conspicuous disclosure in writing, 
9  in a document consisting solely of the disclosure, or obtain from Mr. Lee authorization in writing 
10  to procure a consumer report for employment purposes prior to procuring such a report, as 
11  required by 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(2)(A)(i) and (ii).  Finally, Sterling failed to either inform Mr. 
12  Lee of its reporting to Hertz of public record information likely to adversely affect his ability to 
13  secure employment, or to maintain strict procedures sufficient to ensure that the information was 
14  complete and up to date, prior to delivering the information to Hertz, as required under 15 U.S.C. 
15  § 1681k(a).   
16  86.  Plaintiff’s claims are typical of the claims of the classes he seeks to represent.  
17  Upon information and belief, it is Defendants’ standard practice to take adverse action against 
18  applicants without first providing affected individuals with a copy of their consumer reports and 
19  a written summary of their rights under FCRA.  Additionally, upon information and belief, it is 
20  Hertz’s standard practice to procure consumer reports without first providing a clear and 
21  conspicuous disclosure in writing to applicants, in a document that consists solely of the 
22  disclosure, or obtaining their written authorization.  Finally, upon information and belief, it is 
23  Sterling’s standard practice to deliver to Hertz public-record information likely to prove 
24  detrimental to the ability of applicants to obtain employment without first (a) notifying the 
25  applicants of the fact that the public record information is being reported and the name and 
26  address of the recipient; or (b) maintaining strict procedures to ensure the information is 
27 
28

1  complete and up to date.  Mr. Lee is entitled to relief under the same causes of action as other 
2  Class Members.  
3  87.  Mr. Lee will fairly and adequately represent and protect the interests of the Class 
4  Members.  Mr. Lee has retained counsel who are competent and experienced in complex class 
5  actions, employment litigation, and the intersection thereof.  There is no conflict between Mr. 
6  Lee and the Class Members.  
7  88.  Class certification is appropriate pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil 
8  Procedure 23(b)(2) because the Defendants have acted and/or refused to act on grounds generally 
9  applicable to the Class Members, making declaratory and injunctive relief appropriate with 
10  respect to Mr. Lee and the Class Members as a whole.   The Class Members are entitled to 
11  injunctive relief to end Defendants’ common, uniform, unfair discriminatory—and illegal—
12  policies and practices. 
13  89.   Class certification is also appropriate pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
14  23(b)(3) because common questions of fact and law predominate over any questions affecting 
15  only individual Class Members, and because a class action is superior to other available methods 
16  for the fair and efficient adjudication of this litigation.  Class Members have been damaged and 
17  are entitled to recovery as a result of Defendants’ uniform policies and practices.  Because 
18  Defendants have maintained a common policy of failing to properly inform Class Members of 
19  their rights under FCRA, many Class Members are likely unaware that their rights have been 
20  violated.  
21  90.  The amount of each Class Member’s individual claim is also small compared to 
22  the expense and burden of individual prosecution of this litigation.  The FCRA has statutorily 
23  specified damages, which Class Members will prove at trial are warranted, that will render 
24  calculation of damages for Class Members highly straightforward.  The propriety and amount of 
25  punitive damages are based on Defendants’ conduct, making these issues common to Class 
26  Members.  
27
